title: The NBA has a defensive three seconds problem
description: We looked at the data and found that defensive three seconds doesn’t matter when the game matters.

section.title: The NBA has a defensive three seconds problem
section.text:
A micro-investigation
by Owen Phillips + Russell Goldenberg
section.narration: We looked at the data and found that defensive three seconds doesn’t matter when the game matters.

section.text: Quick refresher on defensive three seconds — basically, the floor is lava.
section.narration: Defenders aren’t allowed to spend more than three seconds in the lane unless they’re guarding someone. It’s a very clear rule, but unlike other fouls, it isn’t called consistently.

section.text: The average defensive three seconds violation comes midway through the second quarter.
section.narration: We’d expect most fouls to occur at the same rate throughout the game, so on average they would be right in the middle.  But when we look at the real data, defensive three seconds leans more towards the first half. Why is that?

section.text: As the game progresses, defensive three seconds is called less often.
section.narration: Maybe teams become more careful about where they stand when the game starts to matter. We don’t think so.

section.text: Want more proof? It was called just once out of 141 occurrences in close games.
section.narration: Between 2015 and 2018, the NBA reviewed the officiating during the last two minutes of over 1400 close games. Somehow the refs missed 99.3% of defensive three seconds.

section.text: If the NBA Is not going to enforce a rule, why have it all?
section.narration: If a player missed 140 out of 141 from the free throw line they’d be out of a job. How many more missed calls before a ref is?
